items.title: Heathrow flights delayed and cancelled as cyber-attack hits European airports
items.standfirst: Attack raises questions over security as Brussels and Berlin airports’ check-in and boarding systems also affectedFlights have been delayed and cancelled at three leading European airports – including London’s largest, Heathrow – after the company behind the software used for check-in and boarding said it was hit by a cyber-attack.Airports in Brussels and Berlin are also experiencing delays and disruption as a result of the problem affecting Collins Aerospace, which works for several airlines at airports across the world. Continue reading...

clusters.title: California bans face coverings for most law enforcement officers during operations
clusters.neutral_headline: California Bans Face Coverings for Law Enforcement
bullet_summary: Reported by Reuters Top News, NPR News, Guardian World

items.title: California bans face coverings for most law enforcement officers during operations
items.standfirst: The ban is a direct response to recent immigration raids in Los Angeles, where federal agents wore masks while making mass arrests. The raids prompted days of protest and led President Donald Trump to deploy National Guard troops and Marines to the area.
items.content: The ban is a direct response to recent immigration raids in Los Angeles, where federal agents wore masks while making mass arrests. The raids prompted days of protest and led President Donald Trump to deploy National Guard troops and Marines to the area.

items.title: California bans masks meant to hide law enforcement officers' identities
items.standfirst: The law, opposed by police organizations, was aimed by lawmakers at immigration agents and will test state powers over the conduct of federal officials.
items.content: The law, opposed by police organizations, was aimed by lawmakers at immigration agents and will test state powers over the conduct of federal officials.(Image credit: Gregory Bull)

items.title: California becomes first state to ban face coverings for most law enforcement
items.standfirst: Local and federal agents, including immigration officials, may not wear masks while conducting official businessCalifornia will be the first state to ban most law enforcement, including federal immigration agents, from covering their faces while conducting official business under a bill signed by the state’s governor, Gavin Newsom, on Saturday.The ban is California’s direct response to a recent series of immigration raids in Los Angeles where federal agents wore masks while making mass arrests. The raids prompted protests and led Donald Trump to deploy national guard troops and marines to the city. Continue reading...
items.content: Local and federal agents, including immigration officials, may not wear masks while conducting official businessCalifornia will be the first state to ban most law enforcement, including federal immigration agents, from covering their faces while conducting official business under a bill signed by the state’s governor, Gavin Newsom, on Saturday.The ban is California’s direct response to a recent series of immigration raids in Los Angeles where federal agents wore masks while making mass arrests. The raids prompted protests and led Donald Trump to deploy national guard troops and marines to the city. Continue reading...

ai_summary: California banned face coverings for most law enforcement officers.
The ban is a response to recent immigration raids in Los Angeles.
The law was opposed by police organizations.
The ban will test state powers over federal officials.
The ban applies to local and federal agents.

Funding ends in ten days, creating a deadline.
Democrats want to extend Obamacare subsidies.
They also want to reverse Medicaid cuts.

clusters.title: Israel attack on Yemeni newspaper was second deadliest on journalists ever recorded
clusters.neutral_headline: Israeli Strikes on Yemen Newspaper Killed Thirty-One Journalists
bullet_summary: Reported by Guardian World, NBC World

items.title: Israel attack on Yemeni newspaper was second deadliest on journalists ever recorded
items.standfirst: Press freedom group says ‘brutal and unjustified attack’ is deadliest since 2009 Maguindanao massacre in PhilippinesThirty one journalists and media staff were killed by Israeli strikes on newspaper offices in Yemen last week in what the Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ) said on Friday was the deadliest attack on journalists in the last 16 years.Israel struck a newspaper complex in Sana’a, Yemen’s capital, which housed three Houthi-connected media outlets on 10 September. At the time, members of the Yemeni army’s press arm were finishing the weekly print edition, according to the publication’s editor-in-chief, which increased the number of journalists present during the strike. Continue reading...
items.content: Press freedom group says ‘brutal and unjustified attack’ is deadliest since 2009 Maguindanao massacre in PhilippinesThirty one journalists and media staff were killed by Israeli strikes on newspaper offices in Yemen last week in what the Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ) said on Friday was the deadliest attack on journalists in the last 16 years.Israel struck a newspaper complex in Sana’a, Yemen’s capital, which housed three Houthi-connected media outlets on 10 September. At the time, members of the Yemeni army’s press arm were finishing the weekly print edition, according to the publication’s editor-in-chief, which increased the number of journalists present during the strike. Continue reading...

items.title: Israeli killing of Yemeni journalists is deadliest attack on press in 16 years, watchdog says
items.standfirst: The Israeli airstrikes that killed 31 journalists and media support workers in Yemen earlier this month were the second-deadliest attack ever on the press, according to a report by the Committee to Protect Journalists, a global watchdog
items.content: The Israeli airstrikes that killed 31 journalists and media support workers in Yemen earlier this month were the second-deadliest attack ever on the press, according to a report by the Committee to Protect Journalists, a global watchdog

ai_summary: Israeli airstrikes on a Yemeni newspaper complex killed thirty-one journalists and media staff.
The Committee to Protect Journalists called it the deadliest attack on journalists in sixteen years.
The attack occurred in Sana'a, Yemen's capital, targeting three Houthi-connected media outlets.
The newspaper's editor-in-chief stated the press arm was finishing the weekly print edition.
This increased the number of journalists present during the Israeli strike on the building.
